newsitem.title: CANADA: Air Canada /Air France lobster split.
newsitem.headline: Air Canada /Air France lobster split.

text.p: After two years of operating joint lobster flights to meet Christmas-New Year demand in France, Air Canada and Air France plan separate programs to meet this year's peak demand for the popular holiday delicacy.
Air France is planning two dedicated B-747 freighter runs from Halifax, and will also carry some lobster traffic to France via its scheduled freighter runs ex-Montreal, said official Alain Vigeant.

Air Canada will ship lobster to France on its Halifax-London flights and by back-hauling lobster from the Atlantic provinces to Montreal and Toronto for transshipment on scheduled passenger flights, an official said. Through December, the daily Montreal-Paris flight is a B-747 combi.

Air Canada also has plans to ferry a B-747 combi without passengers to Paris-Orly in late-December for scheduled maintenance at Air France, and will fill all cargo and baggage space with as much as 60 tonnes of lobster.

Until last spring, Air Canada and Air France were passenger marketing partners, but their only special joint ventures on cargo were the lobster charters. -Air Cargo Newsroom Tel +44 171 542 7706 Fax +44 171 542 5017
